subject: Critical Thinking
title: Bayes' Theorem: Updating Beliefs with New Evidence
description: A quick, practical guide to Bayes' Theorem: Updating Beliefs with New Evidence.

hook.text: A medical test is 99% accurate. You test positive for a disease that affects 1 in 10,000 people.

buildup.text: Bayes' Theorem: P(A|B) = P(B|A) Ã— P(A) / P(B). It calculates how to update prior beliefs with new evidence.

discovery.text: The prior matters enormously. If the disease is rare, even an accurate test produces mostly false positives.

twist.text: Most people ignore the base rate and focus on the test accuracy. Doctors make this error with real patients.

climax.text: Bayesian thinking is the mathematically correct way to learn from evidence.

punchline.text: Don't just ask how strong the evidence is.

quiz.question: Why does a 99% accurate test often produce false positives for rare diseases?
options: When the prior probability is very low, even small false positive rates dominate
